div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: DISTURBANCES AT ERZERUM.
div.p: SULTAN AND BETTER GOVERNMENT.
(Gazette's Special Service.)'
LONDON, Thursday.

The Times" Correspondent at Constantinople states that in some well-informed quarters it is considered that the disturbances amongst the Turkish population in Erzeram will have a good effect. It is argued that the Sultan is too intelligent not to recognize these manifestations of discontent as evidence of the desire of the Turks for better government.

div.head: ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service ).
LONDON, Thursday.

The accounts of the Aboukir Company, Limited, for the past year show that the -profits for the twelve months amount to £28,466, which includes the spm of £5,003 brought forward from the previous year. A dividend of 7 per cent. has been declared on both the Ordinary and Deferred shares, representing a sum of £11,769. £21,700 has been carried forward to the next account.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON, Thursday.

The annual general meeting of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, was held yesterday and produced a chorus of congratulation to the management. Mr. Lang Anderson, after the chairman's speech, pointed out the enormous potential profits in their large agricultural estates. A special resolution was passed. congratulating the Cairo board.

A. Gallant Rescue.

At 6 pm. yesterday a boat laden with tomatoes and with a crew of four natives attempted to enter Alexandria harbour through the aperture in this breakwater known as the ole in the wall." A heavy sea was running, which capsized the boat: One of the occupants, managed to swim to the breakwater, from which be hailed Con Guard patrol boat which was close to on the inside of the breakwater. One of the drew of the bost, Bailor Ali Mitawali Ghaffen, seeing the danger of the remainder of the crew of the capsized boat, at once sprang into the sea and swam to their re cue. Although washed back several times on to the rocks of the breakwater by the waves, thereby gntain ing several ngly at and braises, be peeded in making three reparate journeja, be drowning men safe to land,"

div.head: PETROLEUM IN EGYPT
div.p: A VALUABLE DISCOVERY.
OIL IN PAYABLE QUANTITIES.

The existence of petroleum in Egypt, on the western shore of the Red Sea, has long been known, and the mountain near which oil has been found was known to the ancients as Mons Petrolias. Traces of petroleum are quite ap parent at sea level, and a hole dug on the shore to a level below that of the sea gra- dually fills with salt water with a ecom on the sniface, which increases in thickness, and altimately becomes a layer of dark brown oil, more or less heavy and viscous, as the more volatile components evaporate.

To the south of Gebel Zeit, on the Red Sea, the hore is, broken into two small bays, between which lies, the peninsula of Jemaah Some years ago an expedition was fitted out for the purpose of exploring for oil in this promontory. Shafts were sunk and bore holes were put down, and a small oil supply was reached at a depth of 106 feet, producing about twenty-five barrels a day. A second boring near the first struck oil at a depth of 137 feet and a copious stream of mixed oil and water overflowed the top of the pipe. No accurate measurement was made of the delivery but it was estimated that the amount of oil resulting from this flow was about 1,000 barrels a day. As there were no means at hand.of storing this abundant supply the boring was stopped up, pending future arrangements for development. These facts are taken from Government records.."

Quarre's arose between the explorers and their employers who had sent them cut, and the former closed down the bore holes and obliterated all traces of the expedition, and retired to England in dadgeon. Sabsequent expeditions endeavoured to find the proper. locality, but none of them succeeded, although offe, at least, was equipped and financed by very influential people, and of recent years the quest has been given up.

During the last few weeks the Egyptian Petroleum Company, Ltd., a company regis tered in London, has obtained a concession. over the peninsula of Jemsah to explore for oil. About a month. ago their expedition arrived in Egypt under the guidance of Mr. W. M, Cranston and proceeded to the Red Sea.. One of the members of the expedition was an engineer who had years before put down the wells referred to above, and after a very short preliminary survey the expedition had the Batisfaction of re-opening three of the old wells, two of which showed fall of, petroleum. and the third immediately began to flow at the estimated rate of 30 to 40 tons of oil a day. As this expedition was entirely of a preliminary character these were again closed down and other bore-holes which previously flowed were examined and found to be in a good condition. A large and fally equipped expedition is now in course of formation to develop the oilfield on a commercial basis, That petroleum exists on the concession in payable quantities would appear not to permit of a doubt and the new. expedition will be under the guidance of Sir Roverton Redwood, the eminent oil expert, who very kindly gave his suggestions for the direction of the preliminary expedition which has proved so successful.

The value of this discovery to Egypt cannot be over estimated. A country entirely without fael of any description is under a very great disadvantage, and it is needless to expatiate on the ures to which liquid fuel can be applied in the commercial development of the country. The oil wells are situated within one mile/from the sea, such an accessible. position being unknown in any other oil-field in the world."

div.head: EXPRESS NILE STEAMERS CO.
div.p: The Khedivial sanction has been obtained for the formation of the Express-Nile Steamers Company, Its capital is L.E. 30,000 divide 1 into 7,500 shares of L.E. 4. each, which have been subscrit ed. as follows:-Otto Sterzing, 300 Georges Pangalo, 300; Oscar Emsheimer, 300; Henry H.de Vlies, 3.000; Henry Boutig. ny, 3,000; Gustave Lantié, 300; Paul Vereecken, 300. There, are also 20,000 founders' shares.

The objects of the company are officially stated to be the following:-La Société a pour objet l'entreprise de la navigation sur le Nil dans les conditions résultant des règlements" généraux et spéciaux existants et de ceux qui vichdraient à être mis en vigueur ultérieurement, ainsi que, de toutes éxploitations en dérivant et pouvant y concourir..

Elle pourra entreprendre la construction de bateaux à voile, à vapeur ou mos par toute autre force mécanique ou naturelle, l'entre prise de transport de voyageurs, matériel et marchandises, l'établissement et l'exploitation d'ateliers de toute nature en vue des services de navigation; la pose de voies feriées et leur utilisation, les tractions par voie d'électricité ou de toute autre force motrice et en général les industries complémentaires ou annexes à la navigation sur le Nil.

div.head: THE KHEDIVAH MOTHER
div.p: DERARTS FOR CONSTANTINOPLE
H.H.'s LIFE AT STAMBOUL

Her Highness the Khedivah Mother left Konbbeh for Alexandria yesterday by special train departing at 1.30 p.m. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, Governor of Cairo, and Lewa Mansfield Pacha, Commandant of Police, were at the station:

Her Highness and suite arrived at Alex andria at 5.15 p.m. and proceeded direct to Ras-el-Tin Palace. Thence she immediately left by launch for the Khedivial. Mail Com pany's S.S. Prince Abbas, which has been chartered by her Highness.to convey her to Constantinople.The Khedivah-Mother-remained con board the steamer for the night and in the early hours of this morning (4.15) the Prince Abbas sailed for Constantinople direct, where she is due to arrive on Saturday.
Chafik Bey, the chief of the European and Arabic Cabinet of the Khedive, has been appointed by his. Highness to accompany the Khediyah-Mother to Constantinople.
In view of her Highness's departure from Alexandria for Stamboul, a slight sketch of the Khedivah's life in her Bosphorus, home may
be c

of interest to our readers, Her Highness's Bebek Palace, which replaces the old woodbuilt konak, is not much of an improvement on the old one from an architectural point of view, and for Oriental picturesqueness the quondam building, which although not fireproof like the present, blended better with its surroundings than a Rococo style that includes Pharaonic and Gothic orders. The yali of the late Halim Pacha, by the bye, which is next door, is empty except for a bowab who has little to do beyond sweeping a doorstep. Altogether this yali is in a thoroughly neglected state and would look all the better for a spring cleaning and a less miserable-looking bowab.

But to return to the Khedivah-Mother's Palace. Its gardens can vie with any on the Bosphorus. They are beautifully kept and artistically marked out, A broad gravel path winds through the great green islands of velvet sward, in the middle of which are magnificent magnolia trees, whose lovely flowers diffage their fragrance in the summer air. Besides these, nearly every plant, shrub, and tree is represented; a row of plum, pear, and rhododendron-trees presenting a pleasing prospect of varied foliage along the low wall. I say "low" by comparison with the altitude of the fortress-like ramparts that conceal and guard from dynamitdjis the person of his sacred Majesty.

It is in these fairy-retreats, where the nighting ale sings, that the Khedivah-Mother loves to roam; where she can be at ease and enjoy life. No wonder, then, that she flees the heat of Egypt to this cool bower. She has a fine steamlaunch, 63 feet long, in which she sometimes goes on official visits to Tchibukli and Yenikeni, or makes an oating with the ladies of her Court; but if there is a thing in which her soul delights it is a row in her three-pair oared caique, which, like that of the Greek Patriach, is one of the familiar sights on the Bosphorus. And all those who have travelled in the caique will not marvel at her preference for this means of locomotion, without the smell of engine oil, without noise, except for a rhythmic splash of the glittering oars as they dip into the laughing, sun-kissed waters.

In her Bosphorus home her Highness is an early riser and sometimes breakfasts in the grounds, her tea tray with its silver vessels. being well-known to passers-by as it is carried over the "Rialto bridge into the garden. A pastime of the Khedivah is to drive about in a bullock araba, one of the regular Stamboul kind, only decked, out ingorgeous Turkish draperies, and in this she will spend hours à la Turque, and when tired of it,abe will enter her hill kiosque, and delight in the scene of the natural amphitheatre beneath: the broad bay, the sailing raft of several seas, lively passenger-boats, and, occasionally, an ocean, tramp.

The Khedivah speaks Turkish well, but little French; it is in that latter tongue that she converses with her English lady companion, who, by the bye, was governess to King Alfonso of Spain, and who is a special favourite with her, Highness and accompanies. her everywhere. But, of languages, it is her beloved Arabic that she likes best, and nothing gives her greater joy than when on some summer night, with the glorious moon flooding the Straits, a party of Arab minstrels serenade her from the water: But of late years, owing to the number of political refugees from Constantinople, these moonlight parties have been prohibited, much to the indignation not only of Arab musicians but, the English colonists as well, whose skiffs are as numerous as the British dog-carts of Bang-kok. And so her Highness has now to be content with the plaintive song of the celebrated village owl up in the lindens. yonder, or else to the less soporific strains of an Italian orchestra which performs on Fridays and Sundays in the Municipal Gardens. But of notes, I prefer the voice of the Khedivah's Imam, as it soars into the still night air calling the faithful to prayer in the Oda Alashan Sali.

The Khedivah-Mother's arrival, in Conatantinople is usually the occasion of marked official. ceremony-military excepting on the part of the powers that be. A special aide: de camp or Lord Chamberlain of the Palace, is sent on board the Khedivial yacht to welcome her Highness in the name of, the Padishah. Her first night is usually spent at Yildiz, in the apartments of the Validé Saltans, who, like herself, as the Mother of the People, is the only woman in Turkey allowed to go about unveiled. This privilege of the Khedivah-Mother was, I believe, di-pated by the Tarki h Government, and to day, although the matter is allowed to lapse, the status of the Khedivah-Mother, as with the decorations conferred by the Khediye, is not officially acknowledged, or defined, by the Bawab Ali As a matter of fact, the Press Censor will never allow the use of the title Khediva Valide. Socially, however, the Courts of Yildiz and Abdeen are on the best of terms and everything is done, anoffi cially that can conduce to the comfort of her Highness, An Imperial steam-barge is placed at her disposal and in this she travels to Bebek.

The Khedivial yacht Mahroussa usually anchors ff. Arnsontkeni, a village below Bebek,, and it is interesting to watch the bustle as soon as the Khediy h Mother lands: Ethiopians, lackeys, guards, domestics, hurry: ing hither and thither.

Passing off Beshiktash the Mahroussa's band. plays the Hamidian March, but Arnaontkeni is beyond the reach of the Imperial ear and on a summer's afternoon, Anglo Saxon dom can hear those grand old patriotic strains which can be heard in the E-bekieh: Gardens. The smart appearance of the Egyptian sailors and marines with their dandy canes, compare favourably with the slouching, ill-clad ragamaffins who man the imperial men-of war, and many an envions, if not jealous, eye follows the jolly Gippy as he marches briskly, with an English-look about him, through the bazaars. And yet there are those who are always wondering why E gland does not evachate. Egypt!
AKABA.
Negotiations between the Porte and the Khedive on the subject of the frontier dispute are continuing, but there no progress to report

div.head: EGYPTIAN OPTIONS, LIMITED.
div.p: SURVEY OF CONCESSIONS.
IMPETUS TO MINING INDUSTRY.

Mr. Francis Merton, the consulting engineer and general manager of Egyptian Options, Limited, arrived in Egypt at the end of October last accompanied by Mr. N. Campbell, a well-known surveyor, Mr. Newberry, and Mr. Waddington jquior, with a view of prospecting and making a thorough examination of the Eigat and Jebel Elba concessions on the borders of Egypt and the Sudan, some 230 miles from Asgquan in a south-easterly direction, and about 120 miles from the Red Sea. During the five months they have, been on the ground the party have thoroughly surveyed the conces sions covering 6,000 square miles: both water. and roads have been located and positions fixed. The result of their labours have sur passed Mr. Merton's most sanguine expecta tions. They have discovered on the Bigat concessions three parallel reefs, outcropping for a distance of one mile 250, yards continuously, and all within the average apace of 400 feet the general bearing of the reefs is 20 degrees west of north and the depth is practically vertical; the locality is, mountainous and highly auriferous. The first reef, A., has a depth of 50 feet and a width of 5 feet 4 inches. The result of average samples gives 2 oz. 18. dwt. to the ton; the quartz contains visible gold which was avoided when samples were taken: Seven hundred yards to the south on the same reef quartz was found 11 feet 6 inches wide and the results of average samples give 1 oz 3 dwt. to the ton..

The second reef, B.; is 10 feet 10 inches wide and the results of average samples show 19 dwt. to the ton. Again, 700 yards farther south, a bulk sample taken from this same reef for a width of 2 feet 11 inches, and for a distance of 20 feet showed an average of 1 oz: 10 dwt. to the ton..

The third reef, C., is 7 feet 4 inches in width and the analysis average samples gave 1 oz. 5 dwt. to the ton. Here also the quartz contains visible gold which was avoided when: taking samples. The gold is nitorily disse minated through the quartz and, the ore is free milling.

The principal mine, in Mr. Merton's opinion, was evidently left by the ancient miners in fall working order from.some unknown cause not directly connected with the mine, such as. a war. In proof of this there have been found in the face of some of the workings crude instraments in the shape of broken picks, ironscraper, and a kind of broom, well preserved, which the ancients evidently used to sweep, up their chips after breaking the quartz. This latter is so massive and hard that to break it they used fire to hest the quartz, and the contraction which resulted in cooling sufficed to make the quartz so brittle that it could be chipped off more or less easily. This was evidently the method they employed for breaking the reef in this mine. In some places there were found fireplaces built up against the faceof the reef and remains of their fires in the shape of charcoal and broken chips of stone discoloured by smoke were lying around, which seem to give farther evidence that these mines were abandoned in fall working order; also the stone found at these points showed gold.. It would seem from this raport of Mr. Francis Merton, a well known mining engineer, that we are on the eve of the mining industry in Egypt receiving a considerable impetus. The work would appear to have been done it systematic and practical way, Mr. Merton hav ing proofs for his statements,

On his return to Cairo last week he at once communicated with the Mines Department and applied for mining leases covering the ground which he had pegged out, in accordance with the Government draft regulations of November, 1904. Mr. Merton has paid the necessary rents and the mining leases have been granted to the Egyptian Options, Limited...

Mr. Merton, will be returning to London st the end of May, when he will take the first opportunity of more fully acquainting his shareholders with his wonderful discoveries.. Heintends to take with him a sample ton of the native leavings in the mine to be tested there and which will give a practical proot of their value.

div.head: ERUPTION OF VESUVIUS.
div.p: PREVIOUS CATASTROPHES

The present eraption of Vesuvius appears to be so serious that we shall have to go back as far as Desember 16, 1631, for a precedent to the present catastrophe. On that day, seven currents of lave barst for h at once, and over whelmed several villages at the foot of the mountain. Resins, partly built upon the site of Herculaneum, was consumed by the burning torrents. The inundations of mud were not less destructive than those of the lava itself.. For such is the abundance of rain, owing to the mass of vapours eje ed into the atmosphere, that it precipitates itself along the sides of the cone in actual torrents, charged with s fine impalpable volcanic dust, which carrying. with them fine ashes, acquire a consistence sufficient to justify the name given to them by Lyell, of aq neous lavas." It is believed that 4,000 persons perished in the catastrophe:

Between 1751 and 1872 no less than 33 severe eruptions are recorded, since, which period there have been ejected streams of lava reaching to the foot of the cone, but no erup- Son at all like those of previous years. In November, 1867, after having been quiet for nearly six years, Vesuvius again became active, and has so continued, more or less, almost to the present time. On November 17 in that year-a considerable eruption took place. On March 11, and 12, 1868, the walls of the crater became red with heat, and a fresh tor- rent of lava overflowed in a northerly direction. Showers of stones, etc., were thrown up to a great height, and parts of Naples, Pozzuoli, and other places 10 miles distant were covered with fine volcanic dust. In the preceding January, Resina and Torre del Greco were seriously threatened by streams of lava, which, however, turned aside from them, and subsided amongst other deposits. The grand spectacle attracted crowds of visitors to Naples. The eruption of April, 1872, resulted in very little loss of life, and in no very serions destruction of property.

div.head:
VESUVIUS INVISIBLE.
HORRIBLE GREY DESOLATION.
WHOLE REGION UNDER DENSE PALL.
HEAVY DEATH-ROLL

div.p: Ottajana is smothered with ashes. The popalation of 200 souls are perishing. The volcano resumed activity yesterday evening and is emitting showers of sulphur and sand. Torre del Greco and Torre Annunziata are ont off from Naples. Several correspondents there are anable to leave.
14 dead and 124 injured have been extricat ed from the market here. FIF199 105 bodies have been recovered from, the rains of the church of San Giuseppe..
The King and Queen have given £4,000 to the fund for the sufferera
(Reuter)

The country for miles around Vesovins présents a picture of horrible grey desolation, no vestige of green remsing all towns and villages are more or less eh-buried, some of them six feet deep, recalling the Pompei lisaster. Estimates of the total death roll vary rom five to eight hundred. To-day's accounte re not reassuring. The whole region is under deuse pall; Vesuvias is invisible; frequent arricanes of rain, stones, and ashes are taking place.
The King and Queen have arrived here. (R.)
The King and Queen returned from Rome to isit the victims. The lava to-day is motionless. One hundred and fifty bodies have been reco- ered from the rains of the San Giuseppe hurch. (Harias)

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market
London, April 6,

The Bank rate was yesterday reduced from 4% to 3%, after having stood at the former figure for about six months. Right up to the time of announcement of the reduction there. was great doubt in the City as to what action would be taken by the Bank directors. Of course, there would have been much disap pointment had the decision been other than it was, but nevertheless the directors would have had ample justification had they maintained the higher rate, in view of the state of the French exchange cheque on Paris being then very weak at 25.12. In addition to this, all the available gold in the market was being bought on French account, sovereigns were being taken from the Bank for shipment to South America, and the reserve showed a reduction of two millions:

The fact that the 4% rate was no longer effective no doubt brought its downfall, aided by the disbursement of Government fands, in. the shape of the Consol dividend and the repayment of two millions of Treasury Bille, bat nevertheless, call money, which in the morning commanded 21% to 24%, hardened in the afternoon to 8% and the India Council renewed loans for a month at 23% To-day. loans for the week command 23%, and the discount rate stands at 3% for two and three months bills, with a stiffening tendency.

The Bank return, in addition to the reduc tion in the reserve mentioned above, shows decline of 23,672,000 in Public Deposits. This release of Government funds apparently enabled the market to repay its indebtedness to the Bank, se evidenced by a reduction of £3,200,000 in Other Securities." The "Other 00,000 Deposita", are only £869,000 lower, and the proportion is a shade higher at 451%.
This is anything but a strong return for this. time of the year, and with the French obeque to-day at 25.11, and call money at 19% in New York, the outlook is not all that could be desired.
The Stock Markets,

Notwithstanding the réduction in the Bank rate the stock markets have not responded with increased activity. In fact, yesterday was one of the dullest days ever experienced. The truth of it is that very large issues are impending. Not only Rossis, but. Germany also is under stood to be on the point of issuing a big loan. With regard to the Russian loan, it is said that the dealing in this has already began in Paris, and that the bonds are likely to be issued at a very favourable price, and to go off without difficulty. The issue price is spoken of as 89, and this will of course prove very tempting. In addition to these, there have been placed in London very large amounts of American railway bonds. Such transactions have been very unusual of late years, and these are no doubt the result of the bareness of money in the American markets, These new investments are more attractive than many of those which show an excellent security and a good rate of interest, but which have already had their flatter, and are mostly in the hands of disap Pointed underwriters:
Consols.

The settlement in Console commenced on Tuesday, and the making up price shows a further advance on the previous account of thus making an increase for the two months of. The gilt-edged market has moderately appreciated the better conditions now ruling, and Console closed last night at 90 for cash, after being higher. The closing quotation to-day is 90. DA
Foreign Bonds.

The demand for Japanese stocks referred to in our last letter continued in the early part of this week, bat this has now apparently been satisfied for the present, and interest in the bonds disappeared. Japanese Foura leave off abont higher on the week at 01 Russian securities have been adversely affected by the rumours respecting the new loan, and have lost the good position they had maintained for over a fortnight. The price of the Four per cent is now 83, with little demand for them.
Home Ralls,

On the subject of home railways there is little to say. The market is lifeless, chiefly Owing to the rumour that the Government. intend establishing an eight-hour day for railway employés, a step which would hopelessly cripple the dividenda of many companies. Whilst it is not at all likely that, this will happen, the bare possibility frightens intending. buyers.
Americans.
A very firm tone, has characterised this

market, and prices are higher all round, many of the stocks showing advances of between two and three points. Union Pacifics have been specially favogred, and the quotation for these last night was no less than 5 higher than a week go. The closing prices are as follows: Aitchison, 96 Baltimore, 116 ; Canadian Pacific, 1773 longo and Milwaukee, 182; Brie, 46 xd,linois Gentral, 178.); Louis ville, 155 New York Central, 150; Pennsyl vania hares, 72 ; Philadelphia and Reading, 74. An enormons quan tity of the shares have hanged hands, and they close at the highest, National Bank of Egypt are ex-dividend at 27 and Agricul turals are very good at 10. The reference are 10 and the Debentures 931 Daira Banieb Ordinary are slightly easier at 18 and the. Deferred at 106. The coming meeting of the Egyptian Estates is much looked for, and it is hinted that the report hardly gives a true idea of the won derful success of this undertaking.
Mining.
The South African market is still under a wet blanket, and yesterday, the eve of the carry over, there was no business passing. Prices remain at about last week's levels.

The Egyptian section was unmentioned until yesterday, when Egyptian Options were a good feature, and closed. 11/32 ap.at 1 It is understood. some news as to their success is shortly to be forthcoming. Nile Valleys are 68., neglected at that.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY..."
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT)

London, April 2. The Secretary for War states that the Army Estimates for the financial year on which we have just started bears charges to the amount of £280,000 for the troopa in Egypt and the Sudan. Since 1897, the amount incurred under the Military Works Loans Act is £166,000 in Egypt.

The wildly absurd story is going the rounds that Sir Hector Macdonald is not only alive, but was very mach so during the late Russo- Japanese War, and he is credited with being no other than the invincible Kuroki. The story goes that when Sir Hector came home on the journey which was to be his last, he had been asked by the Jap authorities to join their army. Lord Roberts refused bis

notion and Sir Hector went away, and pretended to commit suicide, and re-appeared as General Kuroki. It may be recalled that Sir Hector's body was never seen by any one who knew him in life, and that Kuroki-never got a public reception after his great victories and that his death has been reported at various times, although he has shown the knack of torning up in action when he was. wanted. Whoever eet this extraordinary yarn. in circulation séema to have forgotten how simple it would have been for the great but unfortunate Sir Heator to have resigned his commission and have joined any army he pleased. Sir Hector was the last man to disappear under the shadow of a shameful charge.

With reference to a resolution passed by the Council of the British Empire League urging the Admiralty to place no unnecessary limit on the numbers to be enrolled in the Colonial nával reserves, either in Newfoundland or Australis, and to afford adequate provision in all cases for their service at sea with a warship, Lord Tweedmouth has addressed a letter to the secretary of the League calling attention to the statement explanatory of the Naval Estimates for 1906 7. From that it would be seen, that as far as the numbers were concerned no change of policy has taken place. The letter proceeds: "The original agreement was that this country should only pay for a limited number of Colo nial Royal reservists, and it would be clearly impossible when the seamen of the Royal Naval Reserve at home are being reduced to go beyond the stipulated number. With refe rence to service in men of war, advocated by Lord Goscher, I may point out that a certain number of Newfoundland reserve men are serving in Commodore Paget's squadron which will arrive in this country early in April."
